REVIEW: Apr 1 2007 	Good Value	Excellent value we stayed for one night which being a Saturday was very expensive on the Strip but cheap here. It is just off the Strip along from Wynns and overlooks the Hilton. Lovely clean room with kitchenette which would have been excellent had we stayed longer.

Jan 19 2007 	Retro Vegas? This is the real thing.	So it's not the Wynn, I still loved it and will stay at the Somerset again. The rooms were large and clean. I never expected to find a room with a built-in kitchen with stove and oven, or the incredible in-room details of vintage, yet simple, space-age light fixtures. Perhaps I'm too easily amused by old-Vegas detail, like the bottle opener installed beneath the bathroom doorknob, but I really enjoyed this place. It's a time warp and very well-maintained which is evident from the roadside and the motel's incredible, enormous, and impeccably-maintained neon signage. There is a bit of owner-pride at this establishment. Sure it's rough around the edges, but you can't beat the price or that old-Vegas style.

Jan 16 2007 	Close but so far	There is no thermostat, meaning that your room is either too hot or too cold. The motel's cheap idea must be to force you to turn off the heat or AC so as to save electricity. The hallway carpets and stairwell emitted a mild odor; the sink drain was rusting; footsteps above my room thundered through a poorly-constructed ceiling; 6:00 A.M. garbage trucks rousted me in my sleep; and the management lost my reservation (bad news during a convention). While the price and location compare favorably with that of other hotels near the LVCC, your experience there will not. Get this: owner Irwin Kishner is a board member of the Nevada Hotel and Lodging Association, which must have an "anything goes" policy. Las Vegas is a city of a wide choice of hotels, and there is no reason for you to be at the low end of the scale.

Nov 20 2006 	Loved This Motel	We couldnt get a room in Vegas for under $350/night so I researched places on-line and because of the positive ratings this motel had, we decided to stay there.Like all the ratings say, this isnt a 5 star hotel, there are no frills, but despite that we loved this place!!!!! The rooms were big, with a small kitchenette and because we smoke we have a balcony. It was like a small one bedroom apartment. The service was great and staff was extremely friendly. Using our AAA card we paid under $50/night and I would have paid $75/night no problem.If you are on a budget or cant find a room I recommend staying here!

Sep 26 2006 	Safe clean choice for low budget	Granted, this place is 40 years old, and seriously shows signs of age and wear, but I get the feeling they sincerely try to keep it up and keep it clean (which I can attest to housekeeping more than diligently doing their job outside my door at 7:10 am on Sunday morning), and cleanliness is what really, really counts for me. I was pleased by the discovery an L-shaped room with of lots of windows that opened, heavy drapes (worn and a little tattered, but clean), a ridiculously large walk-in closet, a sofa bed (worn and lumpy, but also appeared clean, just like the hideous blue carpeting) and a reasonably sized kitchenette, which included a small table and 2 chairs, and an apartment sized stove and fridge, and sink. The bed was kind of lumpy and squeaky, but not uncomfortable  the 3 hours of sleep I got were great and the sheets were clean. The bathroom in my room was as clean as my bathroom at home. I did not check out the pool, but the general pool area looked very well kept. Side note: Some of the rooms have small balconies.If price, cleanliness, and function over form are of more value to you than glitz and being right on the strip, this is a highly recommended choice and is within a very easy, 2 block walk to the strip with ample public transportation in every direction. Traveling as a single female, I felt completely safe at this hotel and the immediate surrounding area, but still - never let your guard down.And, I just loved the old-school Las Vegas broads behind the front desk. I found them to very lovely, genuine people. Don't let their brusque manner fool you, they are really charming and enchanting ladies.

Aug 17 2006 	A Penny Pincher's Paradise	This place is the best value around for the money. So the carpets are a little old and the smell of cigarette smoke lingers in the hall ways. It's got large rooms, comfortable, clean beds, clean bathrooms, and a lot of the rooms have kitchens. If they don't have kitchens they at least have a refrigerator. I feel safe when I'm there. You wouldn't want to stay there for you honeymoon, but for every other occation it's great. I mean, let's face it, it's Las Vegas, the entertainment capital of the world. You go to Vegas because it's Vegas, not to sit in an extravagent room. You can sleep comfortably and shower. That's all you need a room for in Vegas. And if you want you can eat in your kitchen and save some more money too, because if your like me, you like saving money, and that's the reason you stay at the Somerset House.I was first told about this hotel by a friend. I've been traveling to Las Vegas twice a year for the past four years and for the first 2 years I traveled there I used to bounce around from hotel to hotel looking for one that was really worth the money and in a convenient location. This is the only hotel I've stayed at more than once and I made my 4th stay there this past week. It was simply wonderful. If you want anymore info about it I'd be happy to answer your emails at: micah52@verizon.net

Jul 4 2006	good and cheap	This is definatly not the most fancy hotel in Vegas, however for the price it can't be beat. We stayed there for two nights, it is convient close to denny's and walgreens. The strip is right there. I enjoyed it and will stay there again.

May 29 2006	good value of money	Stayed there for two nights in May. Very good location - just one block from the strip, very near to the Riveria and Convention Centre. Although the pool is small however this give us a very good place to enjoy under the sun. One thing I am not satisfied about, which is the quite dirty carpet in the hotel. On the other hand, the room is spacious, it provide good and clean bathroom, well equipped kicthen. I am not happy about the bed which is well too soft.

Dec 23 2005	THE ONLY PLACE WE STAY AT!!!	We have been coming to Las Vegas since 1998. The first year I called a booking agency there in LasVags (as no one would reserve me a room 5 months in advance). They found us a GREAT DEAL at a very well established motel...We didn't finish our stay there it was SO BAD!! The next year I found Somerset online I called and they took my reservations 7 months ahead of our arrival and we have stayed there every year ...except for 3 years ago when we didn't go to LV that year..... The staff are wonderful people who go out of their way to help you any way they can. The rooms are ALWAYS clean and the closet space, hey its another bedroom in those things!! Always lots of towels and HOT WATER and CLEAN BATHROOMS!! The bottom line is this: The Somerset is a older motel that has been well maintained throughout the years. It IS NOT a fancy hotel/motel with room service, mini bars in rooms, big screen T.V.s and all the extra stuff the big name places on the strip have. When we come to Las Vegas and stay at the Somerset, we feel like we are home. Not very many places in LV can do that. Doors are locked around 5PM and the only way you get back in is use your room key OR have the front desk buzz you in.The palce is a safe home away from home place and we wouldn't stay any place else, in fact we told friends and when they go LV they stay at Somerset too.So if you want a clean room, bed, friendly helpful staff, this is the place to stay IF on the other hand you want room service go someplace else but I can guarantee you won't get the safe friendly service from them you get from Somerset..

Dec 8 2005 	Beauty is in the eyes of...........................	I always find it amusing that people stay in cheap places and complain that they aren't as nice as the Paris! Remodeling is expensive and it is paid for by higher prices.The Somerset is convenient......5 minutes to the strip and Walgren's on these aging legs...and 10 minutes to the LV Convention Center. They have cheap rooms especially when booked direct and if you are there at least 7 days, you get an even cheaper rate.I appreciate having a fridge which all rooms have; 80 of the 100+ rooms have kitchenettes.The hallways are depressing, the drapes old, furniture is dated and the kitchen appliances are old and I don't care. I have been in 4 different rooms. All had big closets, clean kitchens, bathrooms and beds. The beds have been the most comfortable that I have been in in LV and the place was the quietest place I have stayed in in my 12 trips. Doors are locked at about 5, and you get buzzed in or use your key. The friendly staff downstairs, maintenance, and housekeeping make the place homey. I sleep 6 hours, shave, shower, and leave. I need a clean bed, bathroom and kitchen and QUIET. The Somersett delivers with that, a great price, and location. If you want great luxury, this is not for you; if you appreciate a good deal, you can live with it.I can afford much better;but I like it there!

Nov 22 2005	good deal - easy walking distance to other places	attended a conference at the Wynn Hotel but could not afford Wynn prices. I stayed at the Somerset House Motel 10/26-10/30/05 and it was fine. Cost of the four days was only $239 which included Fri/Sat night. Sumerset House is within walking distance to the Wynn shuttle or convention center. Staff was very friendly and helpful. Motel is right accross the street from the Greek Isle Casino. I went over there and watched the Rat-Pack Tribute Show.As others pointed out the place is a little old and needs new carpet in the hallways. The room was large, clean and it had a kitchen with fridge (very conveniant to keep drinks cool)& microwave.I would stay there again if I need to be in that part of town for a conference. The price was right for what you get. If you don't need anything super fancy and just a clean place to crash I would recommend the Somerset House Motel.However, this place did not have a clock radio in my room. Had to use my cell phone as an alarm clock.

Nov 14 2005	Best bargain in town	Tourists from America's cow states and sales representatives from the National Blivet Convention prefer Las Vegas' gaudier theme-park hotels on the Strip ("Whoooo-eeeee, Mother . . . 'at hotel looks just like Paris France! . . . look 'a all them fountains, Earl!). Us Vegas regulars don't. Because all we want is a place to sleep. I've been staying here several times a year for a dozen years and wouldn't stay anywhere else. And it has that nice Googie architecture from the late 1950s. Ring-a-ding-ding.

The showers worked and the bathroom was clean. Want luxury? Room service Go to Bally's. Caesar's. etc. Budget minded and simple? This is your place in Vegas.

Sep 19 2005 	Best deal in Vegas	I come into Vegas every weekend for business and I always stay at Somerset House. Its very close to where I work and with a AAA rate of $39 per night on a WEEKEND there is simply no better deal in town.Is it the nicest hotel in Vegas? Definitely not. Floors are creaky, most rooms smell like smoke as do all public hallways, rooms are fairly clean and comfortable but desparately in need of some modern renovating, etc.If youre coming to town with your spouse or bf/gf and want a romantic vacation then do not stay here - this isnt the place. if youre here with buddies and just want a place close to the strip to lay your head for 6-8 hours/day then i think its a great choice.

Jun 14 2005	You do NOT want to stay here	I have stayed at some rather unimpressive places over the years, but I have never been so displeased with a place before to rank it with just one circle. I expected this hotel to be a bit down at the heels because of the inexpensive rates and other reviews and this expectation was confirmed upon arrival. The hallways reeked of cigarette smoke, even on the supposedly non-smoking halls, and the carpets were dirty. Our room was dingy and dirty with some mysterious substance sprayed on the walls. We had chosen the hotel because we wanted a room with a kitchenette. This "kitchenette" did not have a microwave, had an ancient stove that we never turned on as we feared it was a fire hazard, a semi-clogged sink and nothing else, not even a coffee maker although the marquee outside advertised complimentary coffee in every room. When we called down to the desk they told us to call housekeeping (luckily we arrived at 3:30 because after housekeeping leaves at 4 pm you cant get such items), and we were brought a coffee maker, paper plates and cups. At this point we were okay with the room - it was seedy, but we hadn't expected anything great. We unpacked our stuff, turned up the air conditioner and went exploring. It wasn't until we came back to the room out of triple-digit heat and realized that the air conditioner wasn't working that we started to get a bit unhappy. I don't mean it wasn't keeping the room as cool as we wanted, I mean that it wasn't working at all other than making noise. We went down to complain and were treated extremely rudely - the clerk told us it was an old hotel and we couldn't expect the air conditioning to work. We asked to see another room and she said she couldn't show any because of security concerns. We spent the night on the phone trying to find another room somewhere, but as it was Memorial Day week-end we had no luck. We went down the next morning and talked to another clerk who was much nicer. He said they were getting a company called Dependable Air Conditioning to fix it. Well, it never was fixed. We went down again later and they said they hadn't had luck with it and we suspected no one had ever come to look at it. We asked about switching rooms and were told some rooms had working air conditioners but didn't have two beds (we were a party of three) or a kitchenette (we bought a number of items that needed to be refrigerated). In addition, the door could be pushed open about a centimeter even when locked and it appeared as if someone had tried to force it open at some point. I plugged in my cell phone to recharge during the night and discovered in the morning that the outlet had pulled away from the wall. One of the beds had stains that appeared to be blood on the sheets.We went to do laundry, paid a deposit for the key and went outside to the laundry room. The key wouldnt open the door so we went back to ask for help and were told Oh, we thought that was fixed. Then for the grand finale: on our last day I went to take a shower and there was no running water. It did come on again a couple of hours later. We suspected that management wants to unload the hotel and just isnt spending any money on upkeep. The hotel had vacancies every night except for Saturday. We were in and out Saturday and each time we came back the sign would have changed from No Vacancy to Vacancy and vice versa. We had to assume that people were checking in, seeing the condition of the place and checking out and then other poor fools would see the vacancy sign and check-in.

Apr 21 2005	The Sommerset Motel needs to be torn down...	You may save a few bucks staying here but the place is a real dump! The rooms are dusty and need to be thoroughly vacuumed, carpets cleaned, and all scrubbed down. The place is filthy. As far as the kitchenette goes, we had everything styrofoam, which was good! No coffee in the place. The refrigerator was dirty. No screens on the windows. Very scary. The only good things were clean towels and no bed bugs. There was no message service so no one could get ahold of you unless it was an emergency. There was no place to put your luggage if you arrived early and the front desk staff was very rude. The adjacent shopping center was nearly all closed except for an all night joint and dry cleaners. Walgreen's 2 blocks away was the best place to get pop or other snacks at the hotel had nothing. The ice machine was outside and didn't work. Spend a few dollars and stay somewhere else, you will be glad you did.

Great Casino!	It's got some of the cheapest tables on the strip - with $5 minimum bets on let it ride and roulette and other card games. Very useful for those new to casinos and those who dont want to lose all their money too quickly!

Don't overlook this hotel due to location...	I've stayed at this hotel 3 times and really like it. I took my mom for her (58th) birthday last year and she also loved it. The room was nice, clean and the bed was comfortable - we especially loved the pillows ;-). Yes, it's off the strip but there is a bus stop right next to the hotel and for $5 you can get a 24 hr unlimited bus pass (which you can purchase on the bus). If you don't mind walking it's definitely doable.This hotel also has a wonderful 360 view and a revolving restaurant (it's pricy but remember you're also paying for the view and quality of service). We had dinner there which was really good and the waiter was really nice and attentive - even gave my mom a free slice of bday cake.The only negative was the woman walking around taking souvenier pictures - it's was really overpriced and when I said I wasn't interested I didn't finish my sentence she literally grabbed the photos and walked away - not really nice. I almost complained but decided to not let it ruin the night.Just to give you some comparisons of my experience. I've also stayed at the Rio (nice too but it's a mile from the strip and not walkable due to the highway - I tried it and regretted it they do have a shuttle for a fee) and Sahara (simply, won't stay there again) So far, I definitely prefer this hotel. Not as expensive yet the service you get doesn't show it.

Northern Strip	If you want to be right in the thick of things, this isn't the place for you. We, however, didn't want to be. A great smaller hotel and everyone who worked there was simply wonderful. The service level was extraordinary, and I'm hard to please as I work in customer service.
Good Vegas Hotel	Good quality rooms, normal Vegas Casino facilities, about 20 minutes walk to centre of strip.

Nov 26 2009 	Great value and still as good as the last time	The first time I stayed at this hotel was in Jan 2005, when I travelled to Las Vegas by myself and I'm please to say returning 4 years later the standards have not slipped. This hotel is out of the hussle and bussle of the main attractions of the strip, however for the price and quality I don't think anything anywhere else can beat it. If you are someone that wants a decent place to stay and not pay over the odds then this is the place for you. The pool area is great, the choice of food places is great and you'll find that the prices are slightly cheaper than that of other hotels. This time I took my friend and to be honest we didn't mind the walk to the main part of the strip, as it allowed us to view other parts of the strip that you may not bother to go to when you have everything to hand with the hotels that are located centrally. There are shops close by and an internet cafe across the road. Taxis are cheap and not too far from this hotel there is a large shopping outlet, which you will need a taxi to get to. Since 2005 they have created a mono-rail, so if you don't want to take taxis and plan to do several stops on the strip this is a great way to travel. With the exchange rate falling, things are becoming slightly expensive, however still cheaper then the UK. A dinner buffet in most hotels will cost you aboout $22 p/p, however the Stratosphere does a meal deal where you can have a buffett breakfast, lunch and dinner for a set price and if you are a quest you do get a discount on the buffett prices. We spent a lot of time at the pool area during the day and the barman certainly kept us amused. The bar offers snack food which is great if you want a quick bite. Overall this is a great place to stay not only if you are on a budget but if you'd rather splash out in the casino then on your hotel room.

Nov 25 2009 	The view has gone	We did stay here the last night of our trip to this part of the US. The rooms were good, service was fine. I realised that the construction in progress a little down the Strip will eventually ruine the nights' view from this tower. Its unique selling point will at some stage be gone, when they continue to built up this high in front of the tower.

Nov 25 2009 	Great Hotel	I read a lot of reviews about the stratosphere hotel and was initially skeptical. However it is a great place to stay.Our stay was as cheap as chips. We walked it every day to burn off all the food we were eating. You could also catch the deuce for $3 each, catch a taxi to the strip for $15 or get the monorail. But do not be deterred by it's location.The casino itself looks like all other casinos inside with all the poker machines.The rooms were nice and serviced daily. If you want something fancy, go somewhere else but then you will end up paying $100 per night more for the added benefits. This place is great for a cheap getaway and leaves you with money to spend on the more fun things on holiday rather than wasting all your money on a hotel room.

Nov 23 2009 	Great hotel	I sayed in Stratosphere hotel for 3 nights and the room was great. I would recommend this hotel to everyone. If you stay in this hotel you also get free entrance to a Stratosphere tower, where you can enjoy panoramic view and take a ride....Insanity is the best :)

Nov 22 2009 	What a great value! Best Price for a really nice hotel!	I stayed with my friend at the Stratosphere hotel. This wasn't my first stay, I went there with my family several times. Nov 18 2009 	Fun Times	If you like bright lights and excitement within an elevators ride but a nice quiet room, this is the place to go :)

Nov 18 2009 	DO NOT GO HERE	It is important to note that I was a VIP guest as the result of accumulating so many points on previous visit. Antiquated hardware throughout The free suite I was given was adequate but the toilet ran after flushing unless you jiggle the handle or remove the toilet cover and go inside the tank. Peeling paint in the toilet area. This was in a suite. Housekeeping Ridiculous how do you sleep in?Housekeeping is a very efficient operation here. Efficient to the point of discomfort. If you hang the do not disturb sign on your door they will call you that morning at about 1000 hrs to ask you when they can clean your room. YES, they will call between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock to wake you up to ask when they can clean. There seems to be no designated cleaning time as they show up sometimes as late as 2 o'clock in the afternoon. So you can get up and go out and come back in the afternoon and your room is just as you left it in the morning. Room ServiceDefinitely a hit or miss proposition. Sometimes they get it right and sometimes they don't. What is funny is after they get it wrong and they realize it they will call and ask you if everything is okay. This is the ghetto/hood of hotels in Vegas as the result of this some people will be suspect of you. Do not be surprised if you are insulted by someone who works there until you identify yourself as a paying guest. Nov 18 2009 	on the edge of a dicey part of town but cheap !	we booked the stratosphere because we needed a one night stay before goinjg to Zion and Bryce. We knew that it was at the far end of the strip and hadn't planned to walk around, but we were still a bit taken aback by the area. (I still don't know what that means !) It was actually sort of frightening and entertaining at the same time, in a sick kind of way. But, several people seemed to be enjoying themselves, so I guess that's all that matters !From all of my research, I have come to the conclusion that most of the name casinos have cheap rates for really bad rooms. There was a small table and two chairs; the table was rickety and I was afraid it would break apart, but it didn't,The bathroom was dated - the tiles were lie Home Depot construction grade, some sort of cultured marble vanity top and old fixtures. The towels were thin and coarse.Overall, we knew about the poor location relative to the Strip, had low expectations and paid a little more to at least be able to sleep in a decent room. I would have to say that if you know what you are getting into, if you get a cheap rate, it's not too bad. Its location enabled us to quickly get on our way to Zion and Bryce.

Nov 5 2009 	A Holiday Is What You Make It! Quit moaning over the little things and have fun! Nov 5 2009 	Very Nice Treated like a King!	Customer service is everything and they understand it. The new management have turned this hotel/casino around. Excellant customer service. From the telephone booking, to the free upgrade to the top floor when I checked in, to the free all day buffet(without asking for it by pit boss Brian Jacobs), to help making correct bets by pit boss Chuck, to Joel and Johnnie and the others teaching me how to play Crapless craps(a lot of fun), to Security directing me to great Tacos inside the hotel, to the Cabbie teaching me how to get down the strip by taxi without spending a fortune and how to get back without spending a fortune on taxis, to the great maids(the room was spotless). The bedding was very clean and extremly comfortable. Water pressure was a little low but it was in the morning. I gained 10 punds in 4 days. Great buffet. Great all you can eat tacos(real mexican tacos in the sports bar.) After checking in I did not leave the hotel/casino for 27 hours. It is right in the middle between the strip and downtown. Easy to get to both by bus or taxi. I took taxis. $8 to get to Ceasars if you take Industry road instead of the strip. Then get a Taxi at Imperial Palace to get back for next to nothing if they take the back street. A cabbie taught me this. The Casino was brightly lite and clean. The pool was open and great. There was a free full Gym but I did not get to use it. I would add some $3 dollar tables. I went downtown for that. Sometimes you just want to play for fun and not think about the bets. The property and parking structure had security on bikes with bright yellow shirts patrolling all day and night. I felt very safe walking around and leaving my car. I would keep Starbucks open 24 hours. They open at 5 am. Because of the time change I was up at 430 am. I asked Brain Jacobs where I could get a great cup of coffee. Without me asking, he walked over to the bar area and made sure I had a fresh cup of coffee. THAT IS CUSTOMER SERVICE! I will be back.

Nov 4 2009 	WHY such bad reviews?	I can't understand WHY the Stratosphere is getting such bad reviews..I didn't realize they had the rooms I'm reading about! Everytime we come to Vegas, we always try to stay at the Stratosphere...(there's been 2 occasions we stayed elsewhere because PH was just a few bucks more per night...we do our gambling at Strat though!) We always stay in the premier tower and NEVER have any problems...we had adjoining rooms for 3 days with our teenagers and the window in their room was big enough to stand up in, not to mention the amazing view at night! I don't have a single complaint about this place. Housekeeping came by every day. Yeah, it's further down the strip..take the money you saved on the room and get rental car, take the duece or a cab...we chose to walk some days! Who wants to stay in a room when there's soooo much to see in Vegas?!? As far as safety is concerned, our vehicle stayed parked at the property the entire time. We went out to get things all hours of the night, and never felt threathened. There was almost always security patrolling the grounds..even on bicycles. No theft or damage to our vehicle or belongings. No need to feel unsafe :o)My teenagers loved the big shot and the observation deck. It was the very first thing they wanted to do when we checked in..they went up a second time at night before we left..what an amazing view!! The pool was nice..big towels were provided. We ate at Roxy's, Lucky's and a few breakfasts at McDonalds. We planned to eat at the Courtyard Buffett for one day, but the $20 all day deal is for players club members only. We called down before we went and they told us our kids could eat for the $20 per day as well..but that was untrue. They broke the too-good-to-be-true news to us when we went down there. My teenagers are so little, they wouldn't eat $20 worth of food in 2 days..so that wasn't too big a deal! Some of the shops were closed the past few times I was at the Strat. The casino has been one of the better ones to us. My hubby enjoys blackjack, while I'm a slot monkey. We always have a good time and there is never a shortage of cocktails if you TIP your waitress! All in all, the Stratosphere is middle of the road. It's not Planet Hollywood (Prostitute Hub) but it is safe, clean, comfortable and very affordable! We enjoyed our stay and have booked our next trip for March, which we will be staying again at the Stratosphere. It's gonna take more than a few bad reviews to keep me from staying here again!!

I was also 15, so my memory was obviously a little cloudy. This was probably the smokiest casino to walk through which was a turnoff when we first walked in. I paid a little extra for a high floor room with a view - I was a little ticked when my "view" was of the backside of the hotel facing the 'burbs and mountains... not the strip. But whatever, this was just a place to sleep while we explored Vegas so we didn't let it get us down.Take note that this hotel is pretty far away from everything you're probably in Las Vegas to see, unless you want to go to IHOP, get a tatoo, or hit up a quickie wedding chapel. We didn't eat at the hotel (except for a Wetzels Pretzel) but we heard a few bad things about the buffet which made us less enthusiastic about trying the in-house cuisine. It's pretty expensive to eat at the top of the tower, and there wasn't a very good selection on the menu to make it worth our while.I guess everyone has their pet peeves when staying at a hotel. Mine are cleanliness and thin walls. The room was relatively clean, but there were definitly hairs and mystery clumps of stuff in various places in the room. The walls were INCREDIBLY thin. Our next door neighbors woke us up by having the loudest whinist conversation at 3AM - we learned their life story until someone called security to shut them up for about ten minutes before it all began again. Luckily the very comfy bed came with very thick pillows which we put over our heads so we could get a little sleep before heading back out for more fun the next day.There are definitly better choices with comparable prices farther up the Strip, and you can find great deals right in the heart of the Strip if you do some research.

Oct 18 2009 	Good Stay - just some small issues	Booked the Stratosphere 6 months prior to arrival, tried to contact the hotel on several occasions beforehand but no-one wanted to deal with my quieries, asked for the front office manager email address but they wouldnt give it??????8 of us arrived at the hotel, the receptionist where very friendly and check in was very quick, and we all where put on the same floor. the staff at the buffett were excellent, maybe could have had more variety for breakfast food. we had dinner in top of the world restaurant, service was very good, main course let it down slighly, views from the top were excellentthere were 8 of us all guys so plenty of drinking done, $60 a round, but the bar staff where NOT FRIENDLY, one of the guys kept giving us dirty looks and refused to serve us, maybe we should have tipped him more. aksed to speak to the manager but he refused to get him and told me to go to the reception if i wanted one. the bar was filled with prostitutes who would come over and ask if we would like fun, we didnt mind as we had a laugh and a joke with them. but what i found strange was that the bar staff seemed to be telling the girls who to go and talk to, maybe they knew the guys with the most money. Oct 16 2009	Wedding at Chapel in the Clouds-Top of the Stratosphere was PERFECT!!!	We got engaged in Las Vegas in May 2007 and decided to go to the Top of the Stratosphere to see the view of Las Vegas...it was AMAZING...it is just breathtaking up there (especially at night!) I said to my fiance, "I wonder if you could get married up here!" There it started....the planning process! We decided we wanted to get married at the Top of the Stratosphere in Las Vegas! So we did...23 family and friends ended up joining us on May 26th, 2009 and I wouldn't have changed it for anything it was just as I had pictured it =D The view was incredible-we LOVED IT! and our guests definately had not only a wedding they would never forget, but also a trip they would remember for the rest of their lives =) I will now break down my review of the Stratosphere...it is kind of complicated..overall I give it 5 stars-I almost don't want to give it an average rating at all, because at times they went above and beyond for me. For example we had 23 guests and their small chapel only seats 20 people-they upgraded us to the larger chapel for FREE...which I thank them from the bottom of my heart for..I just can't imagine 3 of our guests having to stand after flying from Michigan to Las Vegas to attend our wedding-so that was sooooooo nice of the Stratosphere to do for us!!! When we first started the planning process it was all through email, when you live in another state and you are getting married in Las Vegas....you have to do EVERYTHING through email...you kind of hope for a speedy response..sometime I would get a response the next day, sometimes it would take a week or more! Sometimes if I really needed an answer I would go over my wedding coordinator, who wasn't getting back to me, and send an email to person in charge of Chapel in the Clouds, because she ALWAYS got back to me either the same day or the next day =D Sooooo emails were kind of a pain, but once I figured out that contacting the person in charge (Adel) worked quicker...I contacted her with most of my questions =) Our Minister, Richard was the NICEST guy EVER!!!! We couldn't have picked a better Minister if we tried-the minute we met him, I just loved him! He was great and calmed any nervous feelings we had. He performed a beautiful ceremony and even posed with my grandma and her Elvis shades (I'm a big Elvis fan so all my relatives put on Elvis sunglasses/sideburns at the end of the ceremony to surprise me haha) Richard was a complete sweetheart and I can't thank him enough for making our ceremony so perfect! I wish I would have remembered to give him a big hug at the end of the ceremony. Our Stratosphere Photographer-she had a chip on her shoulder from go, not sure if she just didn't want to be there for the whole whopping 30 minutes she was paid to be there or what, but she was rude and not very pleasant to work with. (I'm not saying it was necessary, but I mean how hard is it to be nice for 30 minutes on people's wedding day!) She wouldn't let any of our relatives take any pictures with flashes on, therefore nobody who took pictures besides her pictures really turned out in the chapel. We were then rushed out of the Chapel and up to the Stratosphere Observation Deck, which is fine cause we were going up there anyways and she took some more pictures, however she managed to get the "No Smoking" sign in most of our pictures. However, I will say any attitude she had didn't bring us down one bit...Richard (the minister) the gorgeous chapel, and THE VIEW of Las Vegas...completely made up for her =D The next day we went to view our pictures and pick the ones for our package (we were to get (1) 8x10 and (3) 4x6's with our package) each additional picture was priced ridiculously high for example (1) 4x6 was $10 each! YIKES...we bought 9 more...so it was $96 and some cents with tax! Anyways our 8x10 was a beautiful picture of us on the observation deck overlooking the strip...with the "No Smoking" sign next to us and I asked if they could please crop out the "No Smoking" sign because I can't see that hanging on our wall with the sign you know...LOL and the woman told me that she wasn't sure...WHAT?! I could crop that out easy with Photo shop myself! Give me a break..anyways she told me she thought they could after a few minutes of looking at it, but that it would have to be shipped to us and that would be an additional $15 for shipping and handeling! I asked when she thought that would get to us and she said probably within 4 to 6 WEEKS! I was stunned...since the picture was supposed to come with our package that we were being charged an EXTRA $15 and it would take 4-6 weeks to get it! Geesh....anything to make a buck I guess...I'm REALLY glad we did the Las Vegas Strip Photo Tour with Toner Photography though for our wedding pictures...we would have only had a couple professional pictures if we went with Stratosphere pictures alone. YIKES! Overall I wouldn't have chose to get married ANYWHERE else in the world-the setting was perfect!!!!

Oct 15 2009 	Lots of walking	Rebooked at the Stratosphere, from The Trump because the Trump didn't have a casino in it. I would never had known that had I not been reading a comment on Trip Advisor. If you stay at the Stratosphere you can go up to the observation desk for free. On the 2nd floor is a Mcdonalds. If you want coffee while getting ready in the morning, you will need to bring your own. The hotels don't provide a coffee maker and if you want a small refigerator, it will cost you $10.00 a day. Had we known how far the hotel was from everything, we would have bought a 3-day Monorail pass. Would have been cheaper. You can take the Deuce (bus) up and down the strip, plus downtown, but it stops frequently. There is an Ihop between the Stratosphere and the Sahara if you want a cheaper breakfast. The Grand Lux Cafe in the Palazzo is a sister cafe to the Cheesecake Factory. There are a couple of good restaurants for lunch, in the Flamingo Hotel that are reasonable. Don't miss the Titanic Exhibit in the Luxor. It will be there for 9 more years. You will see artifacts that were brought up from the ocean floor. Saw the Beatles Love show at the Mirage, The Jersey Boys at the Palazzo and Lance Burton at the Montel Carlo. The Jersey Boys is the number one rated show and it was the best show I think I have ever seen. If you see anymore shows, save this one for the last because no other show will come close to being so good. Next time we will stay at either the Flamingo or Paris since they are more centrally located. On yes, don't miss the fountain water shows at the Belliago. We never saw the same show twice.

Oct 12 2009 	Wet Carpets and Waiting	For our family trip to Las Vegas, we had looked online at various hotels to spend our vacation at. We ultimately decided on checking in at your hotel for the Friday night of the 9th, before we departed during the morning of the 10th. The previous two nights, the 7th and 8th of October were to be spent at the New York, New York. Ultimately, our reasoning for this was to experience different hotels/casinos, explore both ends of the strip, and have a cheaper hotel for the Friday which as well, in the price allowed us to head up the Stratosphere tower which was an attraction we had wanted to see.Our trip up until the 9th was really quite perfect, however, when we arrived at the Stratosphere things started to go south. The area this hotel is in is very sketchy and feels like you are on a side street instead of being on the strip. Checking in went smoothly, and the online reservation was easily looked up and we were booked into a room very close to the pool as requested. However, when we got to our room, we had noticed that the floor was soaking wet and the entire room smelled very strongly of cleaning product. We called the front desk from the room phone, and we were told to wait outside of the room as new cards would be brought up for us immediately. Ten minutes had passed of us waiting outside of the hotel room with all of our luggage and bags so we proceeded to call the front desk again, asking if we could come down and pick up the keys, as waiting in the hallway was not how we wanted to spend our last real day of our vacation. We were then informed that they had just called in for the new keys moments before, and they would be up shortly, and that we should not come down to the front desk. More time passed, as did another phone call down to the front desk, resulting in us again being told they were on their way. We finally got our keys delivered to us outside our room thirty minutes after we had called the front desk. Thirty minutes of having to stand outside of the room, with all of our bags and luggage waiting for a room key.We then proceeded down to our new room, which was conveniently only two doors down. Unfortunately, the floor in this room was again soaking wet, and the room smelled very strongly of cleaning products. At this, we headed downstairs to the front desk, to speak with the manager. We arrived at the desk/check-in area where the manager was, and had been acknowledged by her. She informed us that she was logging on to her terminal, and would help us shortly. We stood there, at the front desk for around 5-10 minutes before we were addressed again by the manager. She was sitting directly in front of us, doing nothing this entire time. At this point, we were fed up, and asked to be refunded for our room and that we would be staying at a different hotel, at this time the manager snapped back at us, asking us why we wanted to receive a refund. At no point prior to this were we asked why we had come to see her. We then stated what had happened with our first room, how long we spent having to wait for a key, and how our second room had the exact same problem. After a bit of discussion, we were checked out of the room, and a refund was issued. We finally got out of the hotel around 4:00pm. We then had to take a monorail back to the southern end of the strip, ($15 for the three of us) and check back in to our first hotel, which cost us $140 more for the night than we were expecting to pay if we had stayed at the Stratosphere. As well, we lost out on our opportunity to go up in the tower for free, which would be included with our room due to checking out from this room and service problem, and decided against paying $15 each to the hotel where we were treated so poorly. After checking back in to the New York New York at around 5:30pm, we headed up to our room to rest after our long journey of checking into the Stratosphere. Needless to say, our last day of our trip was ruined, and we boarded our plane the next morning at 9:45am to head home.

Oct 12 2009 	I heart Las Vegas	Like many other people that have wrote reviews on here about the Stratosphere I was also very worried about what we were going to face when we eventually reached the hotel. But like everyone else we were pleasently surprised. We arrived 2 hours late (thanks Virgin) mid afternoon no queue at rception so checked in straight away needless to say it then took us 10mins just to find the right elevators (un beknown to me we'd booked a premium tower room) which had seperate lifts. Our room 04-11-18 (dont ask bout the way the room numbers work cos i still dont know!) was big with a huge king size bed which I must say was the comfiest ive ever slept on. Bathroom was also nice and big with a long vanity shelf for all my slap! Large window which even tho we didn get a great view was stil nice to get some las vegas sunshine. Room cleaned daily some days it wasnt cleaned til mid afternoon but at least it was still cleaned. Used both the pool on floor 8 and also the 'european' pool on floor 24 both pools fine tho the euro pool on floor 24 was quite difficult to find and once we were there it was free for women but my fiance had to pay 10%, dont think he was too chuffed! bewarned if ur going to the pool to relaxe quietly then sunbathe elsewhere once it hits midday the music by the pool is pretty loud but u get used to it.People are right the casino was a bit grubby and it did smell a bit but then smokings not been banned there yet so think thats the only reason I noticed the smell.Didnt really eat in the hotel except for the buffett breakfast which was awesome an quite reasonable ($13 all u can eat) Mcdonalds and Starbucks in hotel too. The main bar in the middle of casino did all u can drink cocktails daily between 4pm-8pm for $20 which we thought was quite good until one of the bar staff got our drinks wrong an we had to fight just to get it changed- they were the only staff that wernt so helpfull everyone else were amazing. Had one night of luxury eating at the Top of the World restaurant (which revolves) at the top of the tower. This restaurant is very pricey but well worth it (we spent about $200 for 2 courses) the view and food is phenomenal (we ordered gigantic 14oz steak). if ur going make a reservation the first day u get there as its very popular. we requested a table by the window which even tho we were told it wasnt guaranteed we managed to get one which really made the night. As for the location which seems to cause some concern for many people, it is at the end of the strip and it is in a slightly run down area but there was never a time I felt unsafe or uneasy whilst walking to or from the strat hotel. As for homeless people or beggars i dont actually remember seeing that many of them and even the ones we did see didnt bother us at all. The monorail is about a block away its jus round the coner from the Sahara, the only thing I would say is that if ur going to use it go thru the sahara to get to it rather than round the back entrance i felt more uneasy there than i did newhere near the strat. however i found that even just walking to the monorail was tough work (it was 107degrees when we were away) so if id had to walk further down the strip i prob would have passed out so i suppose i can kinda c why the location bothers some. we found it easier jus to get the Duece bus which stops just round the corner from the strat an wa sonly $7 for 24hours and it stops at every hotel along the strip. Some days it does take longer to get down the strip depending on day of the week/ volume of pasengers but it was jus too hot for us to walk a great distance!I would definatly recommend the stratosphere hotel to people looking for doing Vegas on the cheap, this was our first time in Vegas and i think if we'd stayed in a more central hotel it would have been too overwhelming.it definatly broke us in gently lol. However saying that i think next time we'll stay in a more central/luxurious hotel (ive got my eye on the MGM Grand) but would definatly go back to the Stratosphere if we were going to be Las Vegas regulars! ha ha.If uv booked and are worried then please dont cos the strat's fine for what u need it for, its clean with easy access to the strip. I love vegas so much that even tho weve booked to go to the Maldives for our honeymoon next year im trying to persuade my H2B to book vegas instead! ;)Definatly do the Top of the World restauant its pricey but worth itDont try an walk from the strat hotel unless ur going in the winter

Oct 6 2009 	A Positive Experience on Three Separate Visits	This is rather a belated review and is submitted to dispel any feelings of apprehension which may be generated by some of the negative reviews of the hotel and its location. My friend and his wife recently booked a 10 night stay at the Stratosphere based on my recommendation and, after doing so, were somewhat perturbed by some of the reviews on the Trip Advisor Website. The number of negative reviews represents a fractional proportion of the vast number of guests who have stayed at this hotel and have had a very positive experience which includes my wife and myself on two separate visits and latterly a third visit with extended family. These visits were in March, 2007 (4 nights),June, 2007 (7 nights) and October, 2008 (8 nights). The hotel represents great value for money. The rooms were spacious, clean and comfortable. There is a choice of restaurants/diners within the hotel and in particular The Courtyard Buffet which caters for breakfast, lunch and dinner and offers a wide choice of dishes to suit every taste and is very reasonably priced. The Champagne Brunch on a Sunday is not to be missed.You have immediate access to the Stratosphere Tower with its panoramic views of Las Vegas and The Strip in addition to the three "white knuckle" rides at the top of the tower - not for the faint-hearted.The location of the hotel is at the North end of The Strip but did not present any problem at all. The "Deuce" bus stops immediately outside the hotel and will take you up The Strip or alternatively to Downtown Las Vegas and Fremont Street. The light show at Fremont Street is not to be missed. You can buy two types of ticket on the bus - a one way ticket or a 24 hour pass. During our visit the one way ticket was $2 and the 24 hour pass was $5 although this will possibly have increased now. If you are moving up and down The Strip or to Fremont Street, the 24 hour pass is the one to buy. A big plus as regards the location of The Stratosphere is that you will not have a problem boarding the bus outside the hotel. As the run up The Strip progesses the bus gets busier and busier and if you were staying in a hotel in the centre of The Strip, boarding the bus is not so easy. The hotel has an open swimming pool which was fine but we only used this for an hour on one of our visits. If it is your intention to sit around at a swimmimg pool then Las Vegas is not the place for you. There is so much to see and do. Sitting around at a pool seems to defeat the purpose of coming to Las Vegas. Our first visit was for 4 nights which just wasn't sufficient and on returning home, we immediately booked for a further 7 nights some 12 weeks later.

The buffet was reasonable, a nice selection of dishes, and the wait staff were always available. We didn't get to the italian restaurant but heard that it was very nice. The pool was a nice size and not overly crowded. There were always chairs available. There is no shade, however, unless you're lucky enough to get loungers with an umbrella, but who wants shade at a pool anyhow?! The casino floor was easy to navigate, and there was a nice selection of slot machines, tables for black jack, rouellette, etc. We went up to the top of the tower at night and the view was great! It 's free if you're staying there at the stratosphere.We went downtown one night, it only cost about $8 by taxi, and it was a lot of fun. The stratosphere is a bit out of the way being at the north end of the strip but if you're not looking for all that hustle and bustle everyday, it's worth it to stay there and spend a bit of money for monorail ride or the bus or even a taxi to take you to the strip if you want to go. It's a nice place to relax as well as to gamble without all the crowds. We plan on staying at the stratosphere the next time we go to Vegas.

Well starting about 2 days later began noticing skin irritation on my thigh. I thought it was from my underwear so I paid it no mind.The following day my husband began complaining about a rash on his thighs. He thought it came from his pants. The day after that I tried to take a bath in the jacuzzi and couldn't sit in the water because of the burning sensation. The irritation had spread down the back of my legs. So I tell my husband and we compare our skins, which have the same exact rash and bumps. We put 2 and 2 together and called the front desk. We told them we think we've been bit by bed bugs. So they sent security up to take pictures and take a report. He confirmed that it looked as if we had been bitten by something that had caused us to get an infection. Keep in mind we have pictures and videos of all of this. They offer us another room, and that room had a sink leak. The sink was leaking some awful smelling water. Then they offered us another room which was a romance suite and that room was alright, but the cold water to the jacuzzi didn't work. I just said forget it, it was our last night there and also the worst. I was so irritated I couldn't stand any type of heated water and couldn't turn on any cold water. Wow!! They offered us a buffet the next day and to have 3 days taken off of our stay. I immediately called an attorney. We got home on Saturday Oct 3, 2009 and went to the doctor and found out we have SCABIES!! So not only did we get bit the [--] up. It's contagious!! We have 3 small children. 7, 4, and 1. I am livid. I am trying to keep my one year old at a distance so she won't get it and it is so hard, she doesn't understand. I advise anyone not to stay at the stratosphere or the Sahara. I met a woman while I was there that had bites all over her. The Sahara offered her $1,300 and some comedy tickets. A lot more than they offered me. I really thought the stratosphere was nice. Well at least from the pictures the look nice. If you can afford it, it's worth it to just go to one of the newer hotels. Cheaper is not always better. And if you are on a tight budget and absolutely can't afford it do a timeshare. They offer deals for 4 days 2 nights for $99. That's what we should have done, but we didn't find out until we got to vegas. I have to info if you want email me at tiabrunson@yahoo.com. If anyone has had the same experience with stratosphere contact me and we can file a class action suit. They cannot keep getting away with this. We'll update you on our case as it is still new.

Oct 1 2009 	Great Hotel much better than others in same ratings	Have just got back from staying 9 nights at the Stratosphere, and I must say after reading a lot of reviews, before going, I was hesitant. But dont be, checking in was very quick, we arrived on Monday afternoon. When getting to check in the girl was very helpful, and told us we could upgrade, which we did.Our room was on the 16th floor, bedroom plus lounge and fridge, with 2 windows overlooking the mountains, and that cost us an extra $200 for 9 nights, which I thought was very good, room very clean and maid came every day, we could not have been more pleased.We opted for the $19.99 all day buffet most days at hotel, and I must say the choice was endless, breakfast excellent, mid-day excellent, evening meal excellent and had an excellent carvery, with different cuts of roast beef, and turkey, what more could you ask for the money.The hotel is away from the main strip, but we opted for the Deuce bus, though a bit slow, for $7, you get 24 hour pass to ride on or off as many times as you like. And the bus stop is just outside the hotel.I would say the only down side to the hotel is the location, it is not in the best of areas, ok during the day, but be careful at night, there are some undesirables about.But it is nice to get away from the main strip, from all the crowds, and that is what you get staying at the Stratosphere for the money you pay it is could value, we know its not a five star hotel but its better than the hotels near by, Sahara and the Circus.Just one last thing I would say the staff and all the Americans we met where most helpful and polite, and should be proud, they made my wife and myself most welcome.

Oct 1 2009 	This place should be called the CRAPosphere!	I reserved a "Romance suite with a view of the strip" two weeks prior to me staying here at the Stratosphere. Upon check in, the lady at the front desk informed us that the suite I had booked two weeks ago was not available and they had changed our room to a "Star Suite" instead. When we asked her what the difference between the two rooms were she told us the romance comes with an open tub to the living area and the star suite did not. We were in Vegas for our one year wedding anniversary so the open jacuzzi tub was our selling point on booking this suite. After explaining this to the lady, she went to speak with her manager and about ten minutes later comes back and tells us we are going to get a romance suite after all. GOOD. We were charged a $7.50 resort fee daily during our stay here, yet this place is nothing spectacular. We stayed on the 12th floor and had a view of the rooftop of the 11th floor. The carpeting in the hallways is old, and all bunched up in areas. The windows in the rooms do not open so you can not get any fresh air into your room. Our room was a large size but nothing spectacular. This is the only suite I have ever stayed in that came with plastic wrapped plastic cups! No glasses at all. The tub is seperated from the shower which was expected, but what was not expected was the mold inside and on the sides of both. Absolutely disgusting. My husband and I didn't even use the tub the entire stay because if there is mold all over it, it couldn't be very clean. The wall connected to the shower had been molding and rotting away to where there was a hole forming on side where the wall paper and dry wall were missing.The only good thing about this place was the room service. It was quick and not very expensive but my food arrived to my room nice and hot and tasted good. The location of this place is horrible as well. They fail to mention you are about a 2 mile hike to the general fun parts of the strip, be prepared to drive or catch the deuce if you plan on staying here and seeing the strip. It is across the street from Fun City Motel. Very classy! I've stayed at suites all over in Las Vegas and would recommend any of them compared to this Craposphere. For the $400 you will pay for a weekend here at the Stratosphere, you can book a nicer, cleaner, more conveniently located suite at either Palms Place, or The Signature Suites at the MGM. Both are very good values for your money. Don't waste it here!

Sep 28 2009 	A clean value no-frill hotel	I booked this hotel through Pirceline and paid only $40 for one night. At first, I was worried about the quality of the hotel, since it is only a 3-star hotel. However, my view changed when I checked into this hotel. The hotel is very clean, which is a big plus for me. The price is very good as well. The restaurants / food options at this hotel are better and cheaper than Treasure Island I've stayed at. There are couple of things everyone should be aware of: 1) Location: it is a little bit far from the strip. If you don't mind taking the deuce, it should not be too costly to get to the strip. 2) Booking surcharge: when I checked in, they told me that there is an additional $7 daily surcharge for using the gym and the swimming pool. I know that Treasure Island also charge a surcharge to use these facilities. However, Treasure Island DID NOT force people to pay this, whereas the surcharge at Stratosphere is obligatory. On the other hand, there is a very nice outdoor swimming pool that is available at the hotel. Overall, I might not stay at Stratosphere again. Even though the price was reasonable, after the daily surcharge and my taxi fare to get to the strip, it is not much cheaper than other options on the strip. If you plan to stay at the hotel and use all the fitness facilities, it might worth checking out.

Sep 27 2009 	Would have been 4 stars if not for the Resort Fee!	The Stratosphere is not in a good location. We wanted to walk around a little (not go to far) and see what was around the hotel, but nothing was. We could walk to Denny's and that was about it. If we kept walking, we could have walked to the Sahara, but turned around first. The area is a little sketchy. Our room was a premiere room and we only paid $29 a nite for 4 nites. Then, they add a $7.50 a day resort fee. For what? For nothing we used. This is just a way to lure you in for a great price and then just add a fee, in which you have no choice but to pay. Our room was comfy and clean. Our view was of the parking lot (which we could hear clearly car alarms going off). We were on the 14th floor. Again for the price, not too bad.We did not gamble in the Casino, but it was never smokey or loud. We didn't have to walk all the way through the casino to get to the elevator, which was nice. The bathroom was sort of remodeled. The tile around the tub looked new, but the faucet was original. The counter was Corian and plenty of space, but the flooring was original. We got body lotion, shower gel, hand soap, shampoo and conditioner, all of which smelled great.The parking was adequate and free. No problem finding a spot near the parking elevator.Check in was fast and service friendly. Elevators plenty and quick. Good signage throughout. There were cute shops and eating establishments (McDonalds) on the 2nd floor.All in all, the hotel was pretty much what we expected. The room was nice, the location not so nice. Sep 27 2009 	Love this hotel and feel it's excellent value for money.	This was my third stay at the Stratosphere Hotel & Casino. It was easy to get on the Deuce bus, monorail or to take a taxi to wherever we wanted to get to (Downtown and the Strip). The monorail was the quickest and easiest. We were aware through tripadvisor before we arrived that the local area isn't one of the best, but we honestly didn't feel at all threatened or vulnerable in the immediate vicinity.In summary, we would recommend 'The Strat' to anyone who is looking for a great value hotel that provides everything you need without being flash.

Sep 21 2009 	A great hotel at a good price no complaints	Stayed here with a friend for one week on our first trip to Vegas, the hotel stood out at time of booking due to its price. We were pleasantly surprised when we arrived that everything was as expected. The twin room was pretty big and the room was clean, cool and tidy. The hotel is big and the attractions on the roof are an added bonus for the thrill seekers out there.The only criticism is the location, its about a 2.5 miles (4 km) from what you would call 'the strip' and by that I mean the big casinos like Paris, Caesars Palace, Bellagio, TI and Wynn. Getting about is easy enough as we got the monorail from Sahara, which is about a 10 min walk away. Monorails are frequent and journey is approx 20mins. You can walk up the strip no problem, but we found that it took a lot of time stopping at traffic lights (intersections), it took us almost 2 hours to walk up on a busy 'fight' night. There is a bus stop right outside the hotel too, so you can hop of the bus called 'The Deuce' but again the traffic can make the journey take an age.There is not much nearby to do apart from the Stratosphere and the Sahara in the form of entertainment or eating out. We found a local 7-Eleven Gas (Petrol) station that was good for snacks, water and donuts.We enjoyed our stay and would stay again, but if you are looking for something close to the popular hotels and casinos and you don't fancy walking or getting bus / monorail then the Stratosphere may not be for you. For someone in the mid 20s it was no problem.

Sep 19 2009 	great for the price	We recently came back from Veges after spending a week there and staying at the Stratosphere for most of our stay....... after reading all of the reviews we were expecting the worst.... however it was fine, in fact more than fine. The hotel had efficeint check in staff, helpful conceige and was generally a nice place to stay. The hotel has 2 swimming pools 1 on level 8 which is nice, and then 1 on level 24 - now this one is free for ladies to get in and gents have to pay..... it took us a while to figure out why... its a topless area to sunbathe!! oh also Roxys diner does the best milkshakes....... we also ate at the top of the world restaurant at the top of the stratosphere tower, it was pricey but very good food and the views of vegas were fabulous. Location..... ok so yes you are right at the top end of the strip, but the Sahara hotel which is 5 minutes walk has the monorail station which takes you right to all the hotels along the strip - about 5 or 6 stops in total, it runs until 2 or 3am and we found it very efficient. The Stratosphere has a Starbucks so every morning we got our lattes and wandered to the monorail...Grand Canyon..... this is a must do... we went with Pappilon on the first class sunset tour, it was amazing and by going slightly later in the day, when the sun was just setting we saved ourselves from the 42 degree heat - there is no shade in the grand canyon. Other must do..... go and see dolphins at the mirage and the white lions and tigers there too, i could have stayed there all day watching them.... play on craps... its hilarious and we actually won by doing nothing, we weren't big gamblers in vegas we were more interested in seeing the sights so when we did gamble it was just for fun. Shows.... we went to see Jubilee at Ballys which is the longest running show in vegas i think, with the showgirls, lots of bling and feathers and also Cirque du soleil - mystere again the oldest and original - there are 6 cirque du soleil shows in vegas. Both shows were amazing. At the end of our trip we stayed for one night at the bellagio....... OMG amazing..... definately a great way to end our holiday... I cant wait to go back...

Above all, it was VERY clean, neat and tidy and everything worked as it should. The view from both our rooms was very good as well. The hotel eateries were above par and entertaining and the food...oh the food...they sure know how to prepare a fabulous meal!! The Back Alley girls dealers were very unexpectedly very good at what they do...and that includes being knowledgable, helpful and most importantly very easy on the eyes!!! Wow, I have nothing negative to say about The Strat and will be my first choice for when I return!!

Sep 9 2009 	Nice enough to want to return	Just wanted to say that it was very nice to stay at the end of the strip where it was easy to get around from.
